I have a rare congential and progressive disease called KTS. A lot of the body is compromised from vascular system, soft tissues, lymph nodes, cognitive function and bones to name a few, but varies from person to person with KTS. Living with this actually sounds a lot like people who are living with long-term Covid because a lot of symptoms sound like what I have lived with. Anyways, my diet could help, but I like to eat the foods I was raised to eat and can afford, but aren't the best for my condition ...rice and beans. Doctor referred me to a nutritionist who stated I had insulin resistance. I agreed to try the drug Ozempic and at first I had a day or two of light-headedness and nausea. After week 2 I noticed I was doing more and had less pain and on top of that was losing weight. I was on it for a total of 3 months and was ready for a refill. Unfortunately, the $895 cost for 30 day supply, which is a discount, is something I am not willing to pay even if I feel fantastic. I am considering traveling abroad to purchase a 3 month supply, but I wish this was not the case....and after 2 months the pain and stiffness  and weight are back. So my hypothesis is that there is a direct correlation between insulin and bones.

I heard previously, I think from Hank Green either here or on one of his other projects, that the reason why your blood cell factories are inside your bone marrow is because those stem cells are extremely UV sensitive. One of the first things that go wrong in aging and Metabolic Disorder is Calcium and Phosphorus nutrient sensing becoming dysregulated.

If your body can't detect how much calcium and phosphorus is in the blood, it can't utilize it effectively, and even bleeds it out of the bone to excess.

High Fructose Corn Syrup can hammer the 6 Pentose Phosphate Pathways, which plays a role in Calcium/Phosphus metabolism dysfunction. Loss of epigenetic quality control also leads to loss of nutrient sensing.

Perhaps this is part of the reason people assigned female at birth are more likely to get dementia? As they also have more bone issues in later life. Hopefully this will lead to better treatments and preventative measures.

Bones store excess minerals magnesium and potassium as well as sodium and calcium these bone minerals are used in the basic ion transfer process  that delivers glucose to cells.  If the body has a dietary deficit of mineral those bone minerals are extracted from bone storage to keep the ion transfers going. Refilling the bone storage of excess / surplus minerals requires  dietary intake of Vitamin D and K2.  Chronically low mineral levels in the blood can cause bone demineralization/osteoporosis as well as limit Ion transfer failure at the basic cellular level  triggering  muscle  cramps/spasm. This is the reason most doctors will order  an IV of potassium after a stroke or heart attack.
